body:
Looks good for the Flink runner. Overall, this also looks good. This is going in the direction of removing the `stateInternals()` call from `StepContext`, right?

I have some upcoming changes to the Flink operators but they should be easy to integrate. Basically I'm unifying the different operator wrappers and adding support for side inputs. The WIP branch is here if anyone wants to take a look: https://github.com/aljoscha/incubator-beam/commits/flink/streaming-tests

Can a `DoFn` emit values in `teardown()`? If not, then it should be possible to move `setup()` to `open()` (basically the Flink equivalent of `setup()` and `teardown()` to `close()` in the Flink wrappers. I guess the same might hold for Spark.
No, its not that they aren't registered. The issue is that it doesn't make sense to support local paths in Dataflow which Dataflow guards against.
Other than the os.clasifier stuff in the pom.xml, minor comments.

Ken, I commented on PR/681 that we can use a jar that contains all native library variants since only depending on one means that if the client that builds the application is running on an OS which is different than what the runner executes on it will fail to load the native library when executing. Once PR/681 is fixed up, I don't think you'll need to have the maven OS detection plugin.
LGTM
R: @lukecwik

Thank you for review and comments, @dhalperi. I have addressed most of the issues in new commit.

About tests:
I will add a unit test, which mocks AmazonKinesis and runs whole job using direct pipeline runner. This should give us more confidence in the solution.

I'm not aware of any "free" full Kinesis implementation (I've found in-memory kinesis implementation: https://github.com/mhart/kinesalite, but I'm not sure it'll give us more than mocking the AmazonKinesis interface in unit tests). Moreover, Kinesis has no free quota in Amazon, so you need to have billing enabled to use it :(
I took a look at BigTableReadIT test and it seems like I can do a similar thing for Kinesis - then, as you said, someone would need to provide kinesis option to run this and it'll have to be manually enabled.

When I said "run this on real Dataflow" I meant Beam 0.1.0-incubating on Google Cloud Dataflow (as I already said in my previous comment - this is working fine now)

P.S. I can send you my current integration / e2e tests if you'd like to.

[![Coverage Status](https://coveralls.io/builds/6037673/badge)](https://coveralls.io/builds/6037673)

Please manually close the PR at your earliest convenience.
LGTM, thanks!
The edits are big enough that PTAL if you have time -- I actually removed a bunch of unused code in BigQueryTableRowInserter.
Note as well that this will break Dataflow postcommit when first submitted, as the new `RunnableOnService` test will fail. I can alternatively separate the test into a separate PR.
@lukecwik yea, I know. Same answer as @dhalperi there. A bit unfortunate/temporary, but unblocks for now.

@amitsela Travis did pass prior to my opening the PR. Seems there was a Travis timeout/hang in the Mac build. "No output has been received in the last 10m0s, this potentially indicates a stalled build or something wrong with the build itself."

I'll go ahead and rebase to kick Travis and see if it was an infrastructure issue.
R: @dhalperi

It looks like [this](https://github.com/apache/incubator-beam/blob/master/runners/spark/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/runners/spark/translation/SparkProcessContext.java#L257) would be a good place, right ?

I don't think so - that would cause `teardown` to be called before the bundle was 'complete' (given that the code that interacts with the iterator is still waiting to see if it's done or not), which would mean that if it throws an exception we have to discard the (successfully completed) bundle (which I think is incorrect).

Discussed offline a bit, with these conclusions:
- To produce the JSON from the `TransformHierarchy` we are actually going to need this stuff in the SDK, but it should be properly private and have a nice API.
- But we still do need to add the dependency from Dataflow runner to runners-core to eliminate duplication of e.g. `UnboundedReadFromBoundedSource`. But this dependency should be shaded immediately, not left as a future task.

I'll update this PR accordingly.

@aljoscha yes, you are exactly right about the reason behind this. I took a look at your changes and I think there will be no problem. Mostly you'll just get to delete a `throw UnsupportedOperationException` :-)

@lukecwik may be interested to see that you use `StateInternals` to implement side inputs.

[Here](https://github.com/apache/incubator-beam/blob/master/runners/spark/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/runners/spark/translation/DoFnFunction.java#L65) the iterator is called. Maybe after it's complete (successfully) we could call `teardown` ? If `teardown` might throw exception, it could be handled there and decide wether to propagate and fail the `bundle` or not.
I take it back.. this is an iterator implementation, it will actually compute only after it is returned and iterated over.
But the same idea could be applied in my previous idea..
LGTM

@lukecwik thanks for the pointer. I can see a runner wanting to know enough to perform its own validation.

**Bad option**: (strawman to match what we have today): 
- The URN of the UDF clearly identifies it. Problem: there can be no hierarchy with `instanceof` so the cases of interest would have to be enumerated.
- The SDK puts relevant metadata in the SDK-specific payload. Problem: the SDK doesn't necessarily know what is relevant.
- The runner groks the SDK-specific payload. Problem: not language independent, breaking abstraction that is allowed to change whenever. Total non-starter.

**Good option**:
- The UDF envelope has a place for resource/capability requirements, which are a standardized spec.
- The SDK puts relevant metadata in the capability requirements. Same problem as above, but the capability requirement spec lists all the options. An I/O author must consult them, and propose new ones if needed.
- The runner can then decide whether it is able to provide the required capabilities.

Assuming the second choice, we have yet to nail down how such capability requirements should be expressed. It all comes down to the Fn envelope. Great example to work with.
LGTM
Will wait till you merge pr/681 and then update this one to remove references to the OS detection plugin in archetypes as well.
R: @lukecwik
Ah, got it. This is no prob at all. LGTM.

That's where we obtain the `Iterable<OutputT>`, rather than read through all of the elements it contains - so we can't call `teardown` there.

Ideally we would be able to call teardown after the final call to hasNext(), but we would have to do that after the iterator is abandoned, and I can't find anywhere in spark that would provide such a hook.
Conceptually LGTM. An important fix.
Superseded by https://github.com/apache/incubator-beam/pull/691
LGTM

PCollections are just output of PTransforms, and the PTransform nearly always determines their PCoders. The dynamic nature of typing makes this harder, and our type hints are not 1:1 with coders. This is all ripe for cleanup (in particular, we should either determine coders eagerly at pipeline construction, almost like what Java does, or defer all coder checking and validation to a second pass (which would allow us to infer coders in both directions)). 

For now, though, this turns a service bug into a validation check.

There is no such hook, because the API we're looking at is actually _batch_.
For streaming you could do something similar (though the runner is not built that way, currently) as described [here](http://spark.apache.org/docs/latest/streaming-programming-guide.html#design-patterns-for-using-foreachrdd) for managing connections in a pool. 
But we should remember that Spark's DAG execution is lazy, and so `map` transformations that eventually apply `DoFn` are not guaranteed to be evaluated immediately, but only when an `action` is called, so I'm afraid `teardown` will actually happen before any transformation was actually applied to the data in the partitions...

I'm currently working on a new version of the runner working against Spark 2.0 which is more native to the Beam model in many ways.
The Spark 2.0 release (in terms of stream processing) is due any day now, but the first version is considered `alpha` so still much work to do there.
Having said that, I think the current solution here is good enough, as it is mostly batch-oriented. I will take this into account working on the new runner.
BTW that's the new runner's PR [WIP]: https://github.com/apache/incubator-beam/pull/495
@aaltay ping for Python feedback. Its quite a rough WIP.
PTAL
Thank you for the explanations! LGTM

PTAL @dhalperi. It isn't perfect, but the support classes are now package-private. They were previously public and in a namespace we want to remove.

Could move the `getAggregatorSteps` back out, perhaps to some static utility class `Pipelines` or `Aggregators`, but it has to be public somewhere. The support class remains an implementation detail of that one method.
LGTM for Spark runner changes for now, I'm looking into this for the next version of the runner. Thanks!
Thanks for the contribution, merging.
LGTM

Besides that, LGTM.
What does a `local` endpoint mean ? How do other runners execute ? how are they different ? except for supporting different capabilities of the model

That's a really good question, worth nailing down. Intuitively it means "no cluster needs to be set up". I guess the important things would be:
- No set up
- No network needed (so a hermetic test that starts a real non-local cluster won't work)
- No credentials

It applies not just to runners but also to tests. For example, KafkaIO can run an embedded Kafka, and that will work with local Flink & Spark. Whereas Dataflow doesn't have a local version since it is a hosted service.

Does this seem reasonable? If not, is there somewhere we can go with this idea?

Right. Just rebased after the merge of #709 and it is working. And the postcommit has been running successfully all along, and confirmed that it does test all the SDK tests that are pulled in: https://builds.apache.org/view/Beam/job/beam_PostCommit_RunnableOnService_FlinkLocal/org.apache.beam$beam-runners-flink_2.10/6/testReport/
